div.p: Internet Measurements and Public Policy: Mind the Gap
Hadi Asghari * Michel JG van Eeten * Milton L Mueller +
* Delft University of Technology, Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management + Syracuse University, School of Information Studies
Measurement projects (often) fail to have the desired (deserved) impact on cyber policy debates
because of a gap between how computer scientists think of measurement data and how other researchers use it
There is a real need for large scale empirical evidence in policy research (e.g., versus ideas based on hunches, anecdotes or untested models)
Policy makers are very receptive towards empirically backed policy research
So: measurement science and policy research should be a fruitful marriage; however, its often frustrating
Have it run for a while on some infrastructure
Experiment with models, add variables, extract patterns and insights for policy
Caused by different needs & values with regards to data, e.g.: granular vs aggregated, real-time vs historical, etc
Measurement sets ought to keep archives and benefit from being up to date
Providing spatially and temporally aggregated versions of the data is helpful
Due to different units of analysis
Also less to download; solves some privacy issues
Measurements ought to have clear verdicts and interpretations
iv. access to authors / community 25 August 2013 7
Consistency of the measurement instrument and logs over time is important.
E.g., have parallel versions running; monitor test infrastructure, etc.
Data collection should be organized in a manner that promotes sample validity.
